counter

Class AbstractCounter

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Thread
      • counter.AbstractCounter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Counter

    public abstract class AbstractCounter
extends java.lang.Thread
    A simple, potentially shared concurrent, counter class which can print a trace of its behaviour. The non-static methods publicly available are
    • void startCount(): start the counter
    • void stepCount(): step the counter
    • boolean isCountFinished(): has the counter passed its limit?
    The following static methods are also available which will modify the behaviour of all Counters
    • void traceOn(): print a trace of changes to counters to stdout
    • void traceOff(): do not print a trace
    • void setDelay(int delay): slow down counters to increase the chance of time slicing
    Version:
    January 2020
    Author:
    Hugh Osborne

        private int from
        Counting starts at the value "from", takes place in increments of "step", and terminates when the counter passes the "limit" value.

        Counting starts at the value "from", takes place in increments of "step", and terminates when the counter passes the "limit" value.

      • step

        private int step
        Counting starts at the value "from", takes place in increments of "step", and terminates when the counter passes the "limit" value.

      • counter

        private static int counter
        The counter is shared between all instances of AbstractCounter.

      • tracingOn

        private static boolean tracingOn
        Provide a facility for switching tracing on/off. All counters share the same tracing toggle.

      • traceLineNo

        private static int traceLineNo
        It's helpful to have lines in the trace numbered.

      • minimumDelay

        private static int minimumDelay
        A counter will pause, or delay, between each action (starting the count, checking the count's value, stepping the count) by a random time between a minimum and a maximum delay. Delay times are specified in milliseconds.

      • maximumDelay

        private static int maximumDelay
        A counter will pause, or delay, between each action (starting the count, checking the count's value, stepping the count) by a random time between a minimum and a maximum delay. Delay times are specified in milliseconds.

      • random

        private static java.util.Random random
        Used to generate random delays between the minimum and maximum delay values.

    • Constructor Detail

      • AbstractCounter

        public AbstractCounter(java.lang.String name,
                       int from,
                       int limit,
                       int step)
                throws CounterException
        The most detailed constructor, allowing for specification of all parameters of the counter.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of this counter
        from - the value at which the counter starts
        limit - the limiting value (if the counter passes this value counting will stop)
        step - the amount the counter will be incremented by
        Throws:
        CounterException - if:
        • The increment is set to 0 ("step" == 0)
        • The counter counts in the "wrong direction" (e.g. from 0 to 10 in steps of -1)
          • If "limit" > "from" then "step" must be positive
          • If "limit" < "from" then "step" must be negative
          • If "limit" == "from" then it doesn't matter
          I.e. "step"*("limit"-"from") must always be ≥ 0

      • AbstractCounter

        AbstractCounter(int from,
                int limit,
                int step)
         throws CounterException
        Constructor for a "nameless" counter. All other parameters can be specified. A name is generated for the AbstractCounter summarising the values of its parameters.
        Parameters:
        from - the value at which the counter starts
        limit - the limiting value (if the counter passes this value counting will stop)
        step - the amount the counter will be incremented by
        Throws:
        CounterException - if:
        • The increment is set to 0 ("step" == 0)
        • The counter counts in the "wrong direction" (e.g. from 0 to 10 in steps of -1)
          • If "limit" > "from" then "step" must be positive
          • If "limit" < "from" then "step" must be negative
          • If "limit" == "from" then it doesn't matter
          I.e. "step"*("limit"-"from") must always be ≥ 0

      • AbstractCounter

        AbstractCounter(java.lang.String name,
                int from,
                int limit)
        Constructor where the step size is not specified. The step size is set to count by ones in the right direction. I.e.
        • If "limit" > "from" then "step" is set to +1
        • If "limit" < "from" then "step" is set to -1
        • If "limit" == "from" then it doesn't matter what "step" is (here it is set to -1)
        Parameters:
        name - the name of this counter
        from - the value at which the counter starts
        limit - the limiting value (if the counter passes this value counting will stop)

      • AbstractCounter

        public AbstractCounter(int from,
                       int limit)
        "Nameless", "stepless" constructor. A name is generated for the AbstractCounter summarising the values of its parameters. The step size is set to count by ones in the right direction. I.e.
        • If "limit" > "from" then "step" is set to +1
        • If "limit" < "from" then "step" is set to -1
        • If "limit" == "from" then it doesn't matter what "step" is (here it is set to -1)
        Parameters:
        from - the value at which the counter starts
        limit - the limiting value (if the counter passes this value counting will stop)

      • AbstractCounter

        AbstractCounter(java.lang.String name,
                int limit)
        Constructor where neither the step size, nor the initial count is specified. Counting will start at zero. The step size is set to count by ones in the right direction. I.e.
        • If "limit" > 0 then "step" is set to +1
        • If "limit" < 0 then "step" is set to -1
        • If "limit" == 0 then it doesn't matter what "step" is (here it is set to -1)
        Parameters:
        name - the name of this counter
        limit - the limiting value (if the counter passes this value counting will stop)

      • AbstractCounter

        AbstractCounter(int limit)
        A "nameless", "stepless" constructor with no initial count.
        Parameters:
        limit - the limiting value (if the counter passes this value counting will stop) A name is generated for the AbstractCounter summarising the values of its parameters. Counting will start at zero. The step size is set to count by ones in the right direction. I.e.
        • If "limit" > 0 then "step" is set to +1
        • If "limit" < then "step" is set to -1
        • If "limit" == 0 then it doesn't matter what "step" is (here it is set to -1)

      • setDelay

        public static void setDelay(double maximum)
                     throws CounterException
        Set the maximum delay in seconds.
        Parameters:
        maximum - the maximum delay required, in seconds. The minimum delay is set to zero.
        Throws:
        CounterException - if the requested delay is less than zero seconds.

      • setDelay

        public static void setDelay(double minimum,
                            double maximum)
                     throws CounterException
        Set both the minimum and maximum delay in seconds.
        Parameters:
        minimum - the minimum delay desired, in seconds.
        maximum - the maximum delay desired, in seconds.
        Throws:
        CounterException - if the requested maximum delay is not greater than or equal to the requested minimum, or if either of the specified delays is negative.

      • isCountFinished

        public boolean isCountFinished()
        Wait, then check whether the count has reached, or passed this counter's limiting value.
        Returns:
        true iff the count has reached, or passed this counter's limiting value.

      • doCheckIfCountFinished

        protected boolean doCheckIfCountFinished()
        Check whether the count has reached, or passed this counter's limiting value (as an atomic action). The count has reached the limit if the count and the limit are equal. If the increment is positive the count has passed the limit if it is greater than the limit. If the increment is less than zero the count must be lower than its limit.
        Returns:
        true iff the count has reached, or passed this counter's limiting value.

      • endCount

        public void endCount()
        Wait, then end this counter's run,

      • doEndCount

        protected void doEndCount()
        End this counter's run.
